questions.question: Match the following description of ulcers with their causative organisms. 1.Painful vesicular lesions a) Syphilis 2.Painless, beefy red ulcers with rolled edges. b) Chancroid 3.Painless genital ulcer with indurated base. c) Genital herpes 4.Soft, painful genital ulcer with irregular borders. d) Granuloma inguinale
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1-c, 2-d, 3-a, 4-b Explanation: The correct match of the clinical description with their disease is shown below. Ulcer Description Causative Organism 1. Painful vesicular lesions c) Genital herpes 2. Painless, beefy red ulcers with rolled edges d) Granuloma inguinale 3. Painless genital ulcer with indurated base a) Syphilis 4. Soft, painful genital ulcer with irregular borders b) Chancroid Genital herpes presents with painful vesicular lesions & blisters which can burst and cause ulcer formation. It is most commonly caused by HSV-2 > HSV-1. The given image below shows genital herpes. Granuloma inguinale is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It presents with painless, beefy ulcers that may bleed on touch. Microscopically, it shows Donovan body with a safety-pin appearance. The given image shows the clinical picture of the ulcer and Donovan bodies. Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum. It occurs in various stages such as primary, secondary, and tertiary. The primary lesion appears as a regularly edged, regularly based, hard , painless , and button I like ulceration measuring up to 1 cm in diameter. The ulcer is often surrounded by a narrow, red border 1–2 mm wide. The given image shows the primary ulcer. Chancroid is caused by Haemophilus ducreyi. multiple, superficial, tender, soft, ragged ulcers which bleed on manipulation.

questions.question: A 28 year old female presents with vaginal discharge that is frothy, yellow-green in colour and has a foul odour. She reports mild vaginal itching and discomfort during urination. A per speculum reveals the image shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Trichomonas vaginalis Explanation: Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis. It typically presents with the frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a foul odor, along with vaginal itching and discomfort during urination. The characteristic appearance seen is ‘Strawberry cervix,’ an erythematous and edematous cervical mucosa with characteristic punctate red papules. It is caused by microscopic punctate haemorrhages of the cervix. The standard treatment is Metronidazole 2g PO single dose . Features Bacterial Vaginosis Trichomoniasis Candidiasis (Yeast Infection) Discharge Thin, greyish-white,

questions.question: A 28 year old sexually active man presents with painful genital lesions as shown in the image. He reports a tingling sensation and burning pain in the genital area preceding the appearance of the ulcers. Which of the following is the most characteristic finding for his condition?

options.A: The presence of multinucleated giant cells on the Tzanck smear
options.B: Presence of bacterial colonies, "school of fish" appearance on Gram stain
options.C: Donovan bodies within Pund cells on Gram stain

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) The presence of multinucleated giant cells on the Tzanck smear Explanation: Multinucleated giant cells on a Tzanck smear (See image)are characteristic of herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection, particularly herpes genitalis TZANCK smear The presence of painful genital lesions, along with a tingling sensation and burning pain preceding the appearance of ulcers, is highly suggestive of HSV infection. The image shows multiple vesicles and pustules with a coalescing vesicles and erosions as seen in herpes genitalis Herpes genitalis is a sexually transmitted infection caused primarily by HSV-2, although HSV-1 can also be responsible. It is characterised by the infection of genital skin or mucosa Clinical features: Multiple, painful, non-indurated vesicles that may rupture, forming coalescing vesicles or polycyclic erosions. Bilateral tender lymphadenopathy is common. Males: Painful penile ulcerations affecting the glans, prepuce and shaft of the penis Females: Involves external genitalia, vulva, vagina and cervix. Accompanied by dysuria Diagnosis: Tzanck smear,

questions.question: A 35 year old truck driver presents to the clinic with complaints of a painful genital lesion that has been progressively enlarging over the past few weeks. Upon examination, you note a tender ulcerative lesion with undermined edges and a base covered by a greyish exudate. Additionally, there are enlarged and tender inguinal lymph nodes palpable unilaterally. The patient reports a recent sexual encounter with another male truck driver. Which of the following sexually transmitted infections is most likely to present with this clinical manifestation
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Chancroid Explanation: Chancroid caused by Haemophilus ducreyi manifests as multiple ulcers in the genital area, characterized by their non-indurated nature, undermined edges, greyish slough, and tendency to bleed on touch. Individuals with chancroid may develop unilateral, painful lymphadenopathy. The suppurative lymphadenopathy observed in chancroid is termed bubo. Diagnosis Gram staining reveals Gram-negative bacilli arranged in chains, often referred to as "railway tracks" or "school of fish" appearance. Culturing specimens on Mueller Hinton Agar supplemented with chocolate horse blood aids in the identification of Haemophilus ducreyi. Treatment. Azithromycin is administered orally in a single dose of 1 gram OR intramuscular injection of Ceftriaxone at a dosage of 250 mg (single dose) Ulcer Lymph Node Syphilis - treponema Pallidum (Option A) Painless genital ulcer called a chancre Non-tender and rubbery in consistency. Donovanosis - Klebsiella granulomatis (Option B) Painless, beefy red ulcers known as granulomas Pseudo-bubo (enlarged and tender but occurs due to inflammation and not infection) Herpes Simplex (Option C) Grouped vesicles or shallow erosions Multiple, enlarged and inflamed. Lymphogranuloma Venerum (Chlamydia) Solitary and painless. Swollen, inflamed, and fluctuant lymph nodes containing purulent material. Palpable groove or furrow that may be felt in the inguinal region due to the enlargement and fusion of the inguinal lymph nodes. (Groove of Greenlat)

questions.question: A 45 year old male presents to the clinic with painless, beefy-red ulcers on his genitals. He reports that the lesions have been progressively enlarging over the past few weeks. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Oral Azithromycin Explanation: The given clinical presentation of a male with painless, beefy-red ulcers on his genitals with progressive enlargement is suggestive of granuloma inguinale caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. The drug of choice for this condition is oral azithromycin . Donovanosis , also known as granuloma inguinale, is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis bacteria. The characteristic clinical presentation includes painless, beefy-red ulcers that can bleed on touch, with rolled edges and a granular base. Prolonged antibiotic treatment is often necessary. Antibiotics must be given for 3-6 weeks till the ulcer is healed. Drugs include First-line Azithromycin 1g once weekly (or) Azithromycin 500mg daily Second-line Doxycycline 100mg BD (or) Erythromycin 500mg QID (or) Cotrimoxazole 960mg BD Incorrect options: Intramuscular penicillin G (Option B) is used in the treatment of syphilis . Intramuscular ceftriaxone (Option C) is used in the treatment of gonococcal infections. Oral doxycycline (Option D) can be used in the second-line treatment of donovanosis . Reference: Rooks Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page 30.25 https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/donovanosis.htm

questions.question: A 35 year old man presents to a clinic with complaints of painless genital ulcer. He reports that the ulcers have been present for several weeks and have been progressively increasing in size. He also mentions that the ulcers bleed easily upon touch and are not indurated. A picture of the ulcer is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Donovanosis Explanation: The image depicts a beefy-red ulcer with a granulomatous base. The presence of a painless, beefy-red ulcer with a granulomatous base that bleeds easily on touch, indicates a diagnosis of Donovanosis . Characteristic Description Causative Agent Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium Clinical Presentation Painless ulcers or nodules in genital, perianal, or inguinal regions; ulceration with beefy red, granular base Progression Slowly progressive, may lead to extensive tissue destruction if untreated Complications Genital deformity, lymphatic obstruction, secondary bacterial infections Diagnostic Tests Tissue biopsy, Wright or Giemsa staining of tissue samples, PCR for bacterial DNA Treatment Doxycycline (200mg daily) or azithromycin (1g once a week)for 3 weeks Characteristic Donovanosis Syphilis (Option A) Chancroid (Option B) LGV (Option C) Causative Agent Klebsiella granulomatis bacterium Treponema pallidum bacterium

questions.question: A 32 year old male presents to a primary care clinic with complaints of urethral discharge and dysuria. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. On examination, you note purulent discharge from the urethra. Which colour kit would be most appropriate for initial management in this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Grey Explanation: The grey colour kit in the NACO syndromic management approach is used for urethral discharge in males, which is suggestive of possible gonococcal infection (gonorrhoea). STI Color Coded Kits under NACP- 2024: Reference: https://naco.gov.in/sites/default/files/National%20Technical%20Guidelines%20on%20STI%20and%20R TI_Final.pdf

questions.question: A 32 year old woman presents with complaints of vaginal discharge and a fishy odour. She denies any genital itching or irritation. On examination, you notice the discharge coats the vaginal walls as shown in the image. There is no erythema or inflammation noted. Out of the following, which is the single most reliable predictor to support the diagnosis in this patient?

options.A: Presence of clue cells on wet mount microscopy
options.C: Positive whiff test (amine odour) with 10% KOH solution

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Presence of clue cells on wet mount microscopy Explanation: The presence of clue cells on saline wet mount is the single most reliable predictor of bacterial vaginosis. Indicators towards the diagnosis: Presence of fishy-smelling, vaginal discharge without a history of pruritus The image shows a thin, homogenous whitish discharge that coats the walls, characteristic of bacterial vaginosis Clue cells are vaginal epithelial cells that are studded with adherent coccobacilli. This gives the cells a stippled, fuzzy appearance. The

questions.question: A 30 year old woman with a medical history significant for diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic with complaints of vaginal itching and thick, white, curd-like discharge. Physical examination reveals no signs of inflammation or lesions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Vaginal Candidiasis Explanation: Vaginal candidiasis, (yeast infection/ vaginal thrush) is caused by overgrowth of the fungus Candida albicans . Women with diabetes are at higher risk of developing yeast infections due to elevated blood sugar levels, which provide a favourable environment for yeast growth. The symptoms typically include vaginal itching, thick, white, curd-like discharge , and sometimes redness and swelling of the vulva. The absence of inflammation or lesions on examination further supports the diagnosis of vaginal candidiasis Unlike other vaginal discharges, Vaginal pH is usually acidic . Treatment: Topical azole antifungals: Clotrimazole, miconazole, econazole, or tioconazole creams or suppositories Oral azole antifungals: Fluconazole is an effective oral antifungal medication that may be prescribed as a single-dose regimen (150 mg) or as multiple doses depending on the severity of the infection. Bacterial vaginosis (BV) (Option A): It is characterized by a thin, greyish-white discharge with a characteristic fishy odour, known as "whiff test" positivity. Trichomoniasis (Option B): Trichomonal vaginitis typically presents with a frothy, yellow-green vaginal discharge with a characteristic foul odour, often described as "musty." Additionally, patients with trichomoniasis may experience vulvar itching, dyspareunia, and dysuria. Chlamydia trachomatis infection (Option D): Chlamydia trachomatis infection typically presents with mucopurulent cervical discharge. It may lead to complications such as pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) if left untreated.

questions.question: A 28 year old sexually active male presents to the clinic with a painless single lesion on his genitals. On examination, the healthcare provider observes single small, round, painless ulcer with raised edges and a clean base as shown below. The patient denies any recent travel, but he reports having unprotected sexual contact with multiple partners in the past month. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Intramuscular Penicillin G Benzathine Explanation : Based on the clinical presentation of single painless genital ulcer with raised edges and a clean base in a sexually active individual, the most likely diagnosis is syphilis, specifically primary syphilis. Syphilis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. The treatment of choice for all stages of syphilis, including primary

questions.question: A 24-year-old sexually active female presents with dysuria, increased urinary frequency, and mild cervical discharge on per speculum examination.. She denies fever or abdominal pain. A urinalysis reveals pyuria, but no bacteria are seen on Gram staining of the discharge. Which of the following agents is the first-line drug for this condition?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Azithromycin Explanation: The clinical presentation and absence of bacteria on Gram stain suggest Chlamydia trachomatis as the likely cause of non-gonococcal cervicitis . The first-line treatment is a single dose of Azithromycin (1g orally). The diagnosis of NGU/NGC requires the exclusion of gonorrheal infection. This can be achieved with a gram stain that lacks gram-negative diplococci or by any negative gonorrhea test (culture, nucleic acid testing, among others). Chlamydia trachomatis serovars D-K are the most common cause of non-gonococcal urethritis. In females, it can cause various manifestations such as: Mucopurulent cervicitis ( most common ). It may progress to endometritis, salpingitis (fallopian tube), pelvic inflammatory disease, and finally pelvic peritonitis. Perihepatitis ( Fitz–Hugh–Curtis syndrome ). First-line management involves a single oral dose of azithromycin 1g stat. It is preferred due to its greater effectiveness and lower cost . The table below shows the management of uncomplicated chlamydial infections: Non-pregnant First line: Azithromycin 1g single dose Second line: Doxycycline 100mg BD x 7 days Third line: Ofloxacin 200-300mg BD x 7 days Pregnancy First line: Azithromycin 1g oral single dose Second line: Amoxicillin 500mg TDS x 7 days Ceftriaxone (Option B) is used for the treatment of gonococcal infections. Fluconazole (Option C) is used for the treatment of vaginal candidiasis. Doxycycline (Option D) is also highly effective for treating uncomplicated chlamydial infections. It is used when azithromycin is not available or there is a history of allergies. The recommended dose is 100 mg BD x 7 days. Reference: Rook’s Textbook of Dermatology, 9th Edition, Page 30.10-15 Harrison’s Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition Page 1449-50 Essentials of Medical Microbiology, Apurba Sastry, 4th Edition, Page 768, 770 https://w ww.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK535411/#:~:text=The%20diagnosis%20of%20NGU%20requires%20the%20exclusi on%20of%20gonorrheal%20infection.%20This%20can%20be%20achieved%20with%20a%20gram%20stain%20th at%20lacks%20gram%2Dnegative%20diplococci%20or%20by%20any%20negative%20gonorrhea%20test%20(cul ture%2C%20nucleic%20acid%20testing%2C%20among%20others).

questions.question: A 28 year old male presents to the STD clinic with a history of swelling in the inguinal region as shown in the image below. He has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse in the past few months and reports a painless ulcer, which healed without scarring. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?

options.B: Can be associated with hepatitis C co-infection
options.C: Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy
options.D: Esthiomene is a complication in the tertiary stage of this disease

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy Explanation: The given clinical presentation of a male with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse , swelling in the inguinal region (inguinal lymphadenopathy) and a painless ulcer that has healed without scarring is suggestive of lymphogranuloma venerum, caused by Chlamydia trachomatis. The incorrect statement is that it presents with an indurated ulcer and painless lymphadenopathy. Lymphogranuloma venerum (LGV): It is a sexually transmitted disease caused by serovars L1-L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis (M/C strain causing LGV: L2 ). It occurs in sexually active adults of all ages. It can cause LGV-associated proctitis in homosexuals, associated with HIV and hepatitis C co-infection. The incubation period of LGV is around 3-30 days , and the disease presents in three stages,

questions.question: A 28 year old female presents with lower abdominal pain, dyspareunia, and cervical motion tenderness. She also reports that she has been unable to conceive despite actively trying for the past 18 months. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) Chlamydia infection Explanation: The symptoms described in the stem, along with the patient's inability to conceive despite actively trying, raise suspicion of chlamydia infection . Chlamydial pelvic inflammatory disease often presents asymptomatically but can cause symptoms such as lower abdominal pain, dyspareunia, and cervical motion tenderness. These symptoms, along with the patient's reported inability to conceive despite actively trying for the past 18 months, raise suspicion for chlamydial pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which can lead to fallopian tube damage and subsequent infertility . Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of bacterial sexually transmitted infections (STIs). It is caused by the bacterium Chlamydia trachomatis Clinical features in females: Although it is mostly asymptomatic, it can present in the following forms: Cervicitis Urethritis Pelvic inflammatory disease Perihepatitis Pregnancy complications Clinical features in males: Urethritis Epididymitis Prostatitis Common features: Conjunctivitis Pharyngitis Proctitis Genital lymphogranuloma venereum Diagnosis is made through nucleic acid amplification testing (NAAT) of genital samples. Genital herpes (Option A) presents with multiple, painful, non-indurated, umbilicated vesicles that rupture to form coalescing vesicles or polycyclic erosions. Syphilis (Option C) presents as painless genital ulcers (chancre). Trichomoniasis (Option D) presents with frothy discharge, vulvar itching, and strawberry cervix.

questions.question: A 28 year old sexually active male presents with dysuria and urethral discharge which is purulent, profuse, thick and creamy. He reports having unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) IM Ceftriaxone Explanation: Given the symptoms and risk factors, the most likely diagnosis is gonorrhoea. IM ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin antibiotic, is the recommended treatment. Ceftriaxone is typically given as a single dose, often combined with azithromycin to cover potential co-infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. In case of chlamydia the urethral discharge is mucoid/mucopurulent. Treatment regimens in Neisseria infection: Treatment Regimen Dosage/Duration Uncomplicated Gonorrhea Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM (intramuscular) + Azithromycin 1 g orally Single dose OR Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily, Erythromycin 500mg orally QDS daily For 7 days Note: Azithromycin is preferred if chlamydia coinfection is suspected. Alternative Regimen Cefixime 400 mg orally + Azithromycin 1 g orally Single dose OR Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily Erythromycin 500mg orally QDS daily For 7 days Extragenital Gonorrhea (Pharyngeal or Rectal) Ceftriaxone 250 mg IM (intramuscular) + Azithromycin 1 g orally Single dose Single dose OR Doxycycline 100 mg orally twice daily For 7 days Oral fluconazole (Option A): Fluconazole is used for treating fungal infections like vaginal candidiasis. Intramuscular benzathine penicillin G (Option B): Penicillin G is used for treating syphilis, not gonorrhoea. Oral Azithromycin (Option C): Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for gonorrhoea but is not the first-line treatment.

questions.question: A 22 year old sexually active woman presents to the clinic with complaints of vaginal discharge and pelvic pain. She reports having multiple sexual partners and inconsistent use of condoms. On examination, the healthcare provider notices purulent vaginal discharge and tenderness on pelvic examination. A Gram stain of the discharge reveals intracellular gram-negative diplococci. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Gonorrhea Explanation: Gonorrhea is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Additionally, the history of multiple sexual partners and inconsistent condom use is suggestive of a higher risk for STIs, including gonorrhoea. Gram stain showing Neisseria gonorrhoeae Neisseria Gonorrhoea: Characteristic Description Bacterium Gram-negative diplococcus Clinical Presentation Genital discharge (purulent), dysuria, pelvic pain, rectal symptoms Complications Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), epididymitis, prostatitis, disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) Transmission Primarily through sexual contact (vaginal, anal, oral) with an infected individual Risk Factors Unprotected sex, multiple sexual partners, history of gonorrhoea Diagnosis In males, by gram stain(gram negative intracellular diplococci) and culture and in females by culture. Multiplex PCR Treatment SOD cefixime 400mg or intramuscular ceftriaxone 125/250mg as SD Bacterial vaginosis (Option A) is characterized by a thin, greyish-white vaginal discharge with a fishy odour, but it does not present with purulent discharge or intracellular gram-negative diplococci on Gram stain. Candidiasis ( Option B) is a fungal infection that causes vaginal itching and thick, white, cottage cheese-like discharge. Trichomoniasis ( Option C) is caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis and typically presents with frothy, yellow-green, malodorous discharge.

questions.question: A newborn infant presents with symptoms suggestive of congenital syphilis. The mother had untreated syphilis during pregnancy. Which of the following is not a manifestation of early-onset congenital syphilis in newborns?

options.B: Inflammation of oral and nasal mucosa

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Hutchinson’s Triad Hutchinson’s Triad is a feature of the late-onset congenital syphilis. Congenital syphilis occurs when a pregnant woman with untreated syphilis passes the infection to her fetus during pregnancy. The bacterium Treponema pallidum can affect various organ systems in the newborn. The lesions in Congenital syphilis can be classified as Early onset (within 2 years after birth) and Late onset (after 2 years of birth). Lesions in Early Onset Congenital Syphilis: (Options A, B, C ruled out) Vesiculo Bullous rash - Over palms & soles (aka SYPHILITIC PEMPHIGUS) Inflammation of oral and nasal mucosa Continuous discharge from the nose is called snuffles. Wimberger Sign (Bilateral Medial Tibial Erosions) Osteochondritis & Peri Osteochondritis (Pseudo Paralysis of Parrot - Child not able to move) Lesions in Late Onset Congenital Syphilis Hutchison’s Triad: Peg-shaped incisors, interstitial keratitis, and deafness Mulberry Molars Deformed nose Rhagades: Fissures around the mouth Frontal bossing / Olympian bow Higoumenakis Sign (Unilateral Medial Clavicle Periostitis) Cluttons Joint (Painless) Sabre Tibia (Anterior Tibia Periostitis) Reference: Neena Khanna’s Illustrated Synopsis of Dermatology and Sexually Transmitted Diseases, 7th Edition, Page 300

questions.question: A 28 year old man presents to the clinic with a diffuse, maculopapular rash on his palms and soles, as well as fever and sore throat. He reports that the rash developed a few weeks after he noticed a painless ulcer on his genital area, which resolved on its own. The rash is not itchy and does not involve the face. The patient also has white patches in his mouth and a few small, red papules on his genitals. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: D) Secondary Syphilis Explanation: The most likely diagnosis for this patient's presentation is secondary syphilis. Secondary syphilis occurs a few weeks to months after the initial infection (primary syphilis) and is characterized by a variety of symptoms, including a diffuse maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles. Other common features of secondary syphilis include fever, sore throat, and mucous membrane involvement (such as white patches in the mouth). The presence of a painless genital ulcer (chancre) in the history supports the diagnosis. Lesions of Primary Syphilis Lesions of Secondary Syphilis Primary Syphilis genital ulcer Primary syphilis - Penile chancre Chancre - secondary syphilis Characteristic Primary Syphilis Secondary Syphilis Tertiary Syphilis Causative Agent Treponema pallidum bacterium Incubation period 9-90 days after sexual contact 3-12 weeks 24 months Clinical features Single, indurated (button like),painless, clean ulcer which oozes serum on pressure Coppery hyperpigmented, scaly macules or hyperkeratotic papules on palms and soles. condyloma lata in perianal and other intertriginous regions Gumma formation on skin and mucosa ,neurosyphilis, uncomplicated aortitis ,aortic insufficiency ,aneurysm ,coronary stenosis, hepatic gumma Diagnostic Tests Darkground microscopy(cork-screw appearance) Darkground microscopy Blood tests (RPR, VDRL), imaging studies Treatment Benzathine penicillin 2.4 megaunits deep IM In penicillin -sensitive patients- Men and non -pregnant women-Doxycycline 100mg BD x 14d. pregnant women-Erythromycin stearate 500mg QDS x 14d Benzathine penicillin 2.4 megaunits deep IM In penicillin -sensitive patients- Men and non -pregnant women-Doxycycline 100mg BD x 14d. pregnant women-Erythromycin stearate 500mg QDS x 14 Benzathine penicillin 2.4 megaunits IM weekly,x 3 consecutive weeks. In penicillin -sensitive patients- Men and non -pregnant women-Doxycycline 100mg BD x 28d. pregnant women-Erythromycin stearate 500mg QDS x 28d Neurosyphilis-Crystalline penicillin 3-4 units ,4 hourly IV x 14d. Congenital syphilis-Procaine penicillin 50,000units/kg IM daily x 14d.
